document.docAuthor: Qiu, Jian-Yue, Xu, Hao & Chen, Li
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic review of the Oriental flower beetle Coilodera penicillata species complex (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Cetoniinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic review of the Oriental flower beetle Coilodera penicillata species complex (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Cetoniinae)

heading.emphasis:
Coilodera dives ( Gory & Percheron, 1833 )
, revised status

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Coelodera mearsi
(nec Westwood):
Mikšić 1972 : 699
(part, specimens form Assam ).

Coelodera miksici
Antoine, 1986 : 18
(type locality: Shillong, Assam, India), fig. 10a, 10c ♂. New synonym.

/ Ph. ANTOINE det 85.

Comments on type material.
We considered “Himalaya” as the correct type locality of
Coilodera dives
, which we wrote on the lectotype label, even though the collecting site of lectotype was cited as the Malabar coast by Gory & Percheron (1833) . Kapur (1954) also mentioned that specimen(s) of this genus were from Nilgiri hills, southwestern of India . There are many mislabeled cases of Indian species in 19th century and in the flower beetle collection of MHNG ( Arrow 1910 ; Prof. Giulio Cuccodoro, personal communication, November 2015 ), and all species within the species complex are known from the Indo-China subregion ( Fig. 85 ).

Four paratypes ( 1 male and 2 females from Shillong , northeastern India , and 1 female from Mount Victoria , Myanmar ) of
Coilodera miksici
were not found in BMNH and MNHN
. We assume that the depository is probably Antoine’s personal collection as stated in the original publication ( Antoine 1986 ). The female paratype without locality actually is a
Coilodera mearesii
(BMNH, Figs. 13–14 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 4–14. Habitus of

. 4–9,
C. dives
: 4–5, northern Kachin, Myanmar (male); 6–7, Mêdog Xizang (female); 8–9, Mêdog, Xizang (male). 8, Mêdog, Xizang (male). 10–14,
C . mearesii
(male): 10–11, Tiger Hill, northern India; 12, Kurseong, northern India; 13–14, female paratype of
C. miksici
.

Coelodera mearesi Westwood, Ph.
ANTOINE det 85.
Distribution. China : Xizang ( new record ), Yunnan ( new record ); Myanmar ; northeastern India .

Natural history.
Coilodera dives
inhabits tropical areas at the elevations between 1,500–2,000 m ( Figs. 91– 93 ). This species was reported (species misidentified) as commensal species in the wood-feeding cockroach galleries of
Salganea raggei
and
S. matsumotoi
(Blattaria: Blaberidae : Panesthiinae ) in Myanmar (
Kon et al. 2004
;
Maekawa et al. 2005
). We also found several larvae in the galleries of
S. raggei
,
Panesthia agustipennis cognate Bey-Bienko, 1969
(Blattaria: Blaberidae : Panesthiinae ) and
Leptaulax
sp. ( Coleoptera : Passalidae ) in southeastern Tibet in July 2016 ( Figs. 88–89 ), and then brought them back for breeding under artificial environment at room temperature. Most became adults in pupal cells from September to October ( Fig. 90 ). A female was found visiting flower of
Hydrangea
sp. (Rosales: Saxifragaceae ) in August 2017 ( Figs. 86–87 ).

Remarks.
Coilodera dives
has long been regarded as a synonym of
C. penicillata
( Westwood 1842 ; Arrow 1910 ; Schenking 1921 ; Paulian 1960 ; Mikšić 1972 , 1976 ), but it can readily separated by the scutellum, the distal tooth of metatibia, and the parameres; threrfore the species status of
C. dives
is here reinstated. Mikšić examined the lectotype in 1971 and identified it as
C. mearesii
( Figs. 34–36 ), but this was not reported in his taxonomic works on the genus ( Mikšić 1972 , 1976 ). Mikšić (1972) did mentioned that he saw two male specimens from Assam he identified as
C. penicillata
with orange tomentum and the mesometasternal suture distinct with long setae (similar to
C. mearesii
). Later, Antoine (1986) treated them as a new species,
Coilodera miksici
, without comparing with the type series of
C. dives
.
